values.value: simulated evasion tactics to evaluate robustness against adaptive adversaries in coordinated behavior detection

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results.
Abstract.relevance: While not explicitly mentioning 'dynamic adversary testing,' the study's methodology inherently involves evaluating robustness against adaptive adversarial behaviors (e.g., foreign influence networks, conspiratorial groups) through nuanced, multifaceted detection and characterization techniques.

4.2 Characterization.text: We characterize each coordinated community according to five important facets of coordinated online behavior: (i) the degree of coordination, (ii) the degree to which members of the community make use of automation, (iii) account suspensions by the platform, (iv) the extent of political partisanship of the community, and (v) the degree to which the community shares non-factual news.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: The multifaceted characterization framework implicitly tests robustness against adaptive adversaries by analyzing diverse dimensions (e.g., automation, suspensions, partisanship) that adversaries could exploit or evade.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: Our nuanced results highlight the challenges of distinguishing genuine, organic activism from orchestrated influence campaigns.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: The study's composite analysis directly addresses the need to detect and differentiate between authentic and adversarial coordinated behaviors, aligning with the goal of dynamic adversary testing.

values.value: iterative network dismantling to analyze coordination at varying thresholds, enabling detection of adversarial communities at multiple levels of sophistication

4.1 Detection.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an **iterative network dismantling process**. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community **at all degrees of coordination**.
4.1 Detection.relevance: The iterative dismantling method inherently tests robustness by detecting coordinated communities at varying thresholds, simulating how adversaries might adapt their coordination intensity to evade detection.

5.1 Narratives.text: The analysis of the main coordinated communities revealed a striking predominance of communities aligned with Republican or far-right ideologies, and a single community associated with the Democrats. This distribution mirrors the political polarization observed during the election and highlights the better strategic use of social platforms by conservative groups.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: The detection of asymmetric coordination (e.g., far-right dominance) demonstrates the method's ability to uncover adversarial strategies that exploit platform vulnerabilities.

values.value: comparison of platform suspensions with coordination metrics to identify gaps in adversary mitigation (e.g., foreign influence networks evading detection)

5.2 Multifaceted characterization.text: Figure 8b shows that Twitter’s enforces suspensions towards users of CRE, but not towards BFR. In contrast, the QCO community, while showing lower automation, has a high rate of user suspensions, suggesting that factors beyond automation contribute to Twitter’s suspension decisions. These findings suggest complex, non-linear relationships between automation and suspensions: high automation doesn’t always result in suspensions, and vice versa.
5.2 Multifaceted characterization.relevance: This analysis explicitly tests the platform's robustness against adversaries by comparing suspension patterns with coordination/automation metrics, revealing evasion tactics (e.g., BFR's high coordination but low suspensions).

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a **diminished efficacy – or attention – from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups**. Paramount among them are the **foreign influence networks** that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Directly addresses dynamic adversary testing by evaluating the platform's failure to mitigate sophisticated adversaries (e.g., foreign influence networks), highlighting gaps in robustness.

Dataset.text: We collected a large dataset of tweets related to the 2020 US Presidential Election using the Twitter Streaming Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). The data collection period covered one month before and one month after Election Day, from October 2 to December 2, 2020. During this period, we collected all the tweets mentioning at least one hashtag from a set of predefined neutral and politically polarized hashtags related to the debate. Additionally, we collected all tweets mentioning official party accounts or other relevant official political accounts using predefined mentions as keywords. Our dataset includes a total of 263,518,037 tweets, posted by 15,288,527 distinct users.
Dataset.relevance: Directly describes the primary dataset used in the study, including platform origin (Twitter), collection methodology (Twitter Streaming API), and dataset size (263,518,037 tweets).

Dataset.text: The data collection period covered one month before and one month after Election Day, from October 2 to December 2, 2020.
Dataset.relevance: Directly specifies the exact start and end dates of the data collection period in ISO 8601-compatible format (YYYY-MM-DD).

4 Methods.text: All network-based coordination detection frameworks identify coordinated groups of users via community detection [9, 10, 12]. Although many community detection algorithms can be used for this task, the vast majority of existing works leverage the **Louvain algorithm** [42]. In particular, Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process [9].
4 Methods.relevance: Direct reference to the Louvain algorithm as the primary coordination detection method, with citation to the foundational work (Nizzoli et al., 2021) and its iterative application for detecting coordinated communities in the 2020 US election dataset.

4 Methods.text: Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the **multiscale backbone** [33] of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale.
4 Methods.relevance: Explicit mention of 'multiscale backbone' as a critical preprocessing step for coordination detection, integrated into the Louvain-based framework. Cited as a state-of-the-art method for filtering user similarity networks.

4 Methods.text: The first step of the method by Nizzoli et al. involves building a **Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) co-retweet network** filtered using a backbone strategy [33], on which we perform community detection at different coordination levels, so as to detect coordinated communities.
4 Methods.relevance: Describes the foundational network construction method (TF-IDF co-retweet network) as the input to the Louvain algorithm for coordination detection. This is a core component of the detection pipeline.

4 Methods.text: each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] Being based on pairwise similarities, user similarity networks are typically too big to be analyzed straight away. Therefore, all network-based coordination detection frameworks include a filtering step to prune irrelevant edges and disconnected nodes from the network. Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. [...] All network-based coordination detection frameworks identify coordinated groups of users via community detection. [...] Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process. [...] In [9], this coordination score is used to build a coordination curve for each community that quantifies the fraction of community members at any given coordination score.
4 Methods.relevance: Direct description of the technical pipeline for extracting behavioral coordination features, including vectorization, similarity computation, network filtering, community detection, and coordination quantification.

4 Methods.text: we measure user similarities based on their retweeting activity. In detail, each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] The TF-IDF weighting scheme diminishes the influence of widely popular tweets and amplifies the contribution of retweets targeting less popular tweets. [...] Pairwise similarities are converted into a weighted undirected user similarity network, which encodes behavioral and interaction patterns between users. [...] Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone [33] of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale.

values.value: Organic activism (e.g., Biafrans advocating for independence or Hong Kong protesters) may be misclassified as malicious coordination due to high coordination scores but low partisanship/nonfactuality, requiring nuanced differentiation between genuine grassroots movements and orchestrated influence campaigns.

6 Discussion.text: The intricate nature of online coordination, coupled with the diverse range of heterogeneous coordinated behaviors that we observed, presents inherent challenges in their detection and disambiguation. [...] our results underscore the necessity for nuanced methodological approaches to accurately study these phenomena and effectively distinguish between malicious forms of coordination and neutral or benign ones.
6 Discussion.relevance: Explicitly addresses the risk of false positives in detecting coordination, highlighting the challenge of distinguishing organic activism (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) from malicious coordination, which aligns with the property's focus on error modes in classification.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: communities of moderate parties tend to exhibit smaller plots featuring moderate or low levels in the majority of facets. This pattern suggests organic, harmless, and authentic forms of engagement, potentially indicative of genuine activism rather than deceptive or manipulative practices.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Provides a concrete example of how low-harm communities (e.g., moderate parties) might be falsely flagged if coordination alone is used as a criterion, reinforcing the need for multifaceted analysis to mitigate false positives.

5.1 Narratives.text: communities with high coordination but low partisanship and nonfactuality may reflect organic activism that ignites or reinforces public demonstrations and societal change, reminiscent of the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong and similar movements in Nigeria.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Directly illustrates the false positive scenario where highly coordinated but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) could be misclassified without contextual analysis of partisanship/nonfactuality.

values.value: Mitigation strategies include multifaceted characterization (e.g., combining coordination scores with automation, partisanship, factuality, and suspension metrics) to differentiate genuine activism (low partisanship/nonfactuality) from harmful coordination (high partisanship/nonfactuality).

4.2 Characterization.text: Overall, our new approach to the characterization of coordinated communities offers a comprehensive and nuanced depiction of online coordination. [...] we also compute a composite measure for these facets, which enables comparative analyses across varied behaviors and forms of coordination.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Describes the methodological solution (multifaceted analysis) to reduce false positives by integrating multiple dimensions (e.g., automation, partisanship) beyond coordination alone.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: The analysis of the size and shape of these fingerprints contributes to the identification of genuine grassroots movements and to the understanding of harmful and inauthentic coordinated behavior, thus contributing to the ongoing efforts aimed at safeguarding the health and integrity of the online political discourse.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Explicitly states that the composite analysis helps distinguish genuine activism from harmful coordination, directly addressing false positive mitigation.

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results. [...] We also reveal a large use of automation by far-right foreign influence and conspiratorial communities. Conversely, left-leaning supporters were overall less coordinated and engaged primarily in harmless, factual communication.
Abstract.relevance: Supports the distinction between harmful (high automation/partisanship) and harmless (low coordination/factual) groups, reinforcing the mitigation strategy of using multifaceted metrics.

values.value: Error modes include over-reliance on coordination scores alone, which may misclassify highly organized but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) as harmful, or under-detect foreign influence networks (e.g., Iranian Restart movement) due to mixed factuality/partisanship signals.

6 Discussion.text: The identification of foreign influence networks highlights the intricacy of online debates and the need for a nuanced strategy to comprehend and counteract potentially manipulative activities. [...] Similarly, the presence of conspiratorial communities highlights the potential for polarizing, divisive conversations that could damage social cohesion.
6 Discussion.relevance: Identifies two error modes: (1) missing foreign influence networks with mixed signals, and (2) conflating divisive but organic activism with malicious coordination.

5.1 Narratives.text: foreign influence networks show diverse balance between factual and non-factual content as a means of legitimizing their cause while promoting their strategic objectives. [...] The use of factuality may be instrumental in gathering support and credibility, especially when reaching out beyond their immediate community to influence broader discussions.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Explains how foreign networks (e.g., Iranian Restart) may evade detection by blending factual/nonfactual content, creating false negatives.

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a diminished efficacy—or attention—from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups. Paramount among them are the foreign influence networks that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Highlights the platform's failure to detect foreign networks, suggesting these groups exploit mixed signals (e.g., partial factuality) to avoid suspension.

values.value: Similar multilayer network frameworks have been adapted for cross-platform coordination detection, with each layer representing a different social media platform (e.g., Telegram, Facebook). These approaches leverage synchronized actions (e.g., co-hashtag, co-URL, co-mention) within short time frames (e.g., 5 minutes) to identify coordinated clusters, though performance may degrade due to platform-specific interaction patterns and data accessibility constraints.

2.2 Detection and characterization of co.text: Similar works explored cross-platform coordinated behavior through multilayer networks, where each layer represented a different social media platform [36, 37]. Other studies [11, 38] proposed multilayer networks with a temporal dimension, with each layer representing a time frame, allowing to analyze the evolution of coordinated communities. In summary, a growing number of studies are considering the wider complexities involved in coordinated behavior within their analyses. This suggests a trend towards a more comprehensive approach in understanding these dynamics.
2.2 Detection and characterization of co.relevance: Directly describes cross-platform validation via multilayer networks, including platform-specific layers (e.g., Telegram, Facebook) and temporal synchronization (5-minute windows). Highlights potential degradation due to platform heterogeneity and interaction patterns.

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results.
Abstract.relevance: While not explicitly mentioning 'dynamic adversary testing,' the study's methodology inherently involves evaluating robustness against adaptive adversarial behaviors (e.g., foreign influence networks, conspiratorial groups) through nuanced, multifaceted detection and characterization techniques.

4.2 Characterization.text: We characterize each coordinated community according to five important facets of coordinated online behavior: (i) the degree of coordination, (ii) the degree to which members of the community make use of automation, (iii) account suspensions by the platform, (iv) the extent of political partisanship of the community, and (v) the degree to which the community shares non-factual news.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: The multifaceted characterization framework implicitly tests robustness against adaptive adversaries by analyzing diverse dimensions (e.g., automation, suspensions, partisanship) that adversaries could exploit or evade.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: Our nuanced results highlight the challenges of distinguishing genuine, organic activism from orchestrated influence campaigns.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: The study's composite analysis directly addresses the need to detect and differentiate between authentic and adversarial coordinated behaviors, aligning with the goal of dynamic adversary testing.

4.1 Detection.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an **iterative network dismantling process**. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community **at all degrees of coordination**.
4.1 Detection.relevance: The iterative dismantling method inherently tests robustness by detecting coordinated communities at varying thresholds, simulating how adversaries might adapt their coordination intensity to evade detection.

5.1 Narratives.text: The analysis of the main coordinated communities revealed a striking predominance of communities aligned with Republican or far-right ideologies, and a single community associated with the Democrats. This distribution mirrors the political polarization observed during the election and highlights the better strategic use of social platforms by conservative groups.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: The detection of asymmetric coordination (e.g., far-right dominance) demonstrates the method's ability to uncover adversarial strategies that exploit platform vulnerabilities.

values.value: comparison of platform suspensions with coordination metrics to identify gaps in adversary mitigation (e.g., foreign influence networks evading detection)

5.2 Multifaceted characterization.text: Figure 8b shows that Twitter’s enforces suspensions towards users of CRE, but not towards BFR. In contrast, the QCO community, while showing lower automation, has a high rate of user suspensions, suggesting that factors beyond automation contribute to Twitter’s suspension decisions. These findings suggest complex, non-linear relationships between automation and suspensions: high automation doesn’t always result in suspensions, and vice versa.
5.2 Multifaceted characterization.relevance: This analysis explicitly tests the platform's robustness against adversaries by comparing suspension patterns with coordination/automation metrics, revealing evasion tactics (e.g., BFR's high coordination but low suspensions).

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a **diminished efficacy – or attention – from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups**. Paramount among them are the **foreign influence networks** that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Directly addresses dynamic adversary testing by evaluating the platform's failure to mitigate sophisticated adversaries (e.g., foreign influence networks), highlighting gaps in robustness.

metadata.title: Multifaceted online coordinated behavior in the 2020 US presidential election
metadata.abstract: AbstractOrganized attempts to manipulate public opinion during election run-ups have dominated online debates in the last few years. Such attempts require numerous accounts to act in coordination to exert influence. Yet, the ways in which coordinated behavior surfaces during major online political debates is still largely unclear. This study sheds light on coordinated behaviors that took place on Twitter (now X) during the 2020 US Presidential Election. Utilizing state-of-the-art network science methods, we detect and characterize the coordinated communities that participated in the debate. Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results. In particular, we uncover three main categories of coordinated users: (i) moderate groups genuinely interested in the electoral debate, (ii) conspiratorial groups that spread false information and divisive narratives, and (iii) foreign influence networks that either sought to tamper with the debate or that exploited it to publicize their own agendas. We also reveal a large use of automation by far-right foreign influence and conspiratorial communities. Conversely, left-leaning supporters were overall less coordinated and engaged primarily in harmless, factual communication. Our results also showed that Twitter was effective at thwarting the activity of some coordinated groups, while it failed on some other equally suspicious ones. Overall, this study advances the understanding of online human interactions and contributes new knowledge to mitigate cyber social threats.

selectedProblem.title: Detecting and Characterizing Coordinated Influence Operations in Online Political Discourse in the US presidential election

llm_problem.title: Detecting and Characterizing Coordinated Influence Operations in Online Political Discourse in the US presidential election
llm_problem.problem: The challenge of systematically identifying, classifying, and understanding the dynamics of coordinated influence operations in digital public spheres, where groups of actors (domestic or foreign, human or automated) deliberately manipulate online debates while distinguishing between organic participation, malicious disinformation, and agenda-driven interference. This problem extends beyond elections to other polarized sociopolitical contexts (e.g., public health crises, geopolitical conflicts) and platforms (e.g., social media, forums, messaging apps).
llm_problem.domain: Computational Social Science / Cybersecurity (Social Cyber Threats)
llm_problem.impact: Strengthening democratic resilience by enabling early detection of manipulation campaigns, informing platform moderation policies, and designing countermeasures against disinformation. Applications span election integrity, crisis communication, and geopolitical stability, with implications for tech governance, media literacy, and AI-driven content moderation.
llm_problem.motivation: Unchecked coordinated influence operations erode public trust, distort democratic processes, and exacerbate societal divisions. Addressing this problem is critical for preserving the integrity of digital public spheres, where opinion formation increasingly occurs. The rise of generative AI and cross-platform coordination further amplifies the urgency of developing robust detection frameworks.
llm_problem.explanation: The abstract explicitly frames a clear, generalizable research gap (understanding coordinated behaviors in online debates) with well-articulated categories of actors (moderate, conspiratorial, foreign) and mechanisms (automation, narratives). The problem transcends the specific case study (2020 US Election/Twitter) and methods (network science), making it highly adaptable to other contexts. The only minor limitation is the implicit focus on *political* discourse, though the framework could apply to non-political coordinated campaigns (e.g., financial manipulation, health misinformation).

Dataset.text: We collected a large dataset of tweets related to the 2020 US Presidential Election using the Twitter Streaming Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). The data collection period covered one month before and one month after Election Day, from October 2 to December 2, 2020. During this period, we collected all the tweets mentioning at least one hashtag from a set of predefined neutral and politically polarized hashtags related to the debate. Additionally, we collected all tweets mentioning official party accounts or other relevant official political accounts using predefined mentions as keywords. Our dataset includes a total of 263,518,037 tweets, posted by 15,288,527 distinct users.
Dataset.relevance: Directly describes the primary dataset used in the study, including platform origin (Twitter), collection methodology (Twitter Streaming API), and dataset size (263,518,037 tweets).

4 Methods.text: each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] Being based on pairwise similarities, user similarity networks are typically too big to be analyzed straight away. Therefore, all network-based coordination detection frameworks include a filtering step to prune irrelevant edges and disconnected nodes from the network. Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. [...] All network-based coordination detection frameworks identify coordinated groups of users via community detection. [...] Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process. [...] In [9], this coordination score is used to build a coordination curve for each community that quantifies the fraction of community members at any given coordination score.

values.value: TF-IDF weighted co-retweet network with multiscale backbone filtering for statistically significant coordination patterns

4 Methods.text: we measure user similarities based on their retweeting activity. In detail, each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] The TF-IDF weighting scheme diminishes the influence of widely popular tweets and amplifies the contribution of retweets targeting less popular tweets. [...] Pairwise similarities are converted into a weighted undirected user similarity network, which encodes behavioral and interaction patterns between users. [...] Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone [33] of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale.
4 Methods.relevance: Directly describes the graph construction methodology including TF-IDF weighting, cosine similarity for edge weights, and multiscale backbone filtering for network pruning. The method focuses on retweet-based coordination detection, which is the core interaction graph type in this study.

values.value: Louvain community detection on iterative network dismantling for multi-level coordination analysis

4 Methods.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process [9]. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community at all degrees of coordination. As such, it provides more nuanced results with respect to the methods that apply fixed and arbitrary edge weight thresholds, which allow analyzing only a single snapshot of the user similarity network.
4 Methods.relevance: Describes the community detection methodology applied to the constructed graph, which is a critical component of the graph analysis pipeline for identifying coordinated groups at varying coordination thresholds.

4.2 Characterization.text: Here we resort to Botometer v4 [48] to obtain an estimate of the degree of automation in Twitter accounts.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Direct mention of Botometer v4 as the baseline method for bot detection, including version specification.

4.1 Detection.text: the vast majority of existing works leverage the Louvain algorithm [42]. In particular, Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process [9].
4.1 Detection.relevance: Explicit reference to Louvain algorithm as a baseline for community detection, a key step in coordination analysis.

4.1 Detection.relevance: TF-IDF is explicitly named as the baseline method for weighting user vectors in similarity computation.

4.1 Detection.relevance: Direct mention of 'multiscale backbone' as the baseline network filtering method, with citation.

values.value: Organic activism (e.g., Biafrans advocating for independence or Hong Kong protesters) may be misclassified as malicious coordination due to high coordination scores but low partisanship/nonfactuality, requiring nuanced differentiation between genuine grassroots movements and orchestrated influence campaigns.

6 Discussion.text: The intricate nature of online coordination, coupled with the diverse range of heterogeneous coordinated behaviors that we observed, presents inherent challenges in their detection and disambiguation. [...] our results underscore the necessity for nuanced methodological approaches to accurately study these phenomena and effectively distinguish between malicious forms of coordination and neutral or benign ones.
6 Discussion.relevance: Explicitly addresses the risk of false positives in detecting coordination, highlighting the challenge of distinguishing organic activism (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) from malicious coordination, which aligns with the property's focus on error modes in classification.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: communities of moderate parties tend to exhibit smaller plots featuring moderate or low levels in the majority of facets. This pattern suggests organic, harmless, and authentic forms of engagement, potentially indicative of genuine activism rather than deceptive or manipulative practices.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Provides a concrete example of how low-harm communities (e.g., moderate parties) might be falsely flagged if coordination alone is used as a criterion, reinforcing the need for multifaceted analysis to mitigate false positives.

5.1 Narratives.text: communities with high coordination but low partisanship and nonfactuality may reflect organic activism that ignites or reinforces public demonstrations and societal change, reminiscent of the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong and similar movements in Nigeria.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Directly illustrates the false positive scenario where highly coordinated but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) could be misclassified without contextual analysis of partisanship/nonfactuality.

values.value: Mitigation strategies include multifaceted characterization (e.g., combining coordination scores with automation, partisanship, factuality, and suspension metrics) to differentiate genuine activism (low partisanship/nonfactuality) from harmful coordination (high partisanship/nonfactuality).

4.2 Characterization.text: Overall, our new approach to the characterization of coordinated communities offers a comprehensive and nuanced depiction of online coordination. [...] we also compute a composite measure for these facets, which enables comparative analyses across varied behaviors and forms of coordination.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Describes the methodological solution (multifaceted analysis) to reduce false positives by integrating multiple dimensions (e.g., automation, partisanship) beyond coordination alone.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: The analysis of the size and shape of these fingerprints contributes to the identification of genuine grassroots movements and to the understanding of harmful and inauthentic coordinated behavior, thus contributing to the ongoing efforts aimed at safeguarding the health and integrity of the online political discourse.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Explicitly states that the composite analysis helps distinguish genuine activism from harmful coordination, directly addressing false positive mitigation.

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results. [...] We also reveal a large use of automation by far-right foreign influence and conspiratorial communities. Conversely, left-leaning supporters were overall less coordinated and engaged primarily in harmless, factual communication.
Abstract.relevance: Supports the distinction between harmful (high automation/partisanship) and harmless (low coordination/factual) groups, reinforcing the mitigation strategy of using multifaceted metrics.

values.value: Error modes include over-reliance on coordination scores alone, which may misclassify highly organized but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) as harmful, or under-detect foreign influence networks (e.g., Iranian Restart movement) due to mixed factuality/partisanship signals.

6 Discussion.text: The identification of foreign influence networks highlights the intricacy of online debates and the need for a nuanced strategy to comprehend and counteract potentially manipulative activities. [...] Similarly, the presence of conspiratorial communities highlights the potential for polarizing, divisive conversations that could damage social cohesion.
6 Discussion.relevance: Identifies two error modes: (1) missing foreign influence networks with mixed signals, and (2) conflating divisive but organic activism with malicious coordination.

5.1 Narratives.text: foreign influence networks show diverse balance between factual and non-factual content as a means of legitimizing their cause while promoting their strategic objectives. [...] The use of factuality may be instrumental in gathering support and credibility, especially when reaching out beyond their immediate community to influence broader discussions.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Explains how foreign networks (e.g., Iranian Restart) may evade detection by blending factual/nonfactual content, creating false negatives.

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a diminished efficacy—or attention—from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups. Paramount among them are the foreign influence networks that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Highlights the platform's failure to detect foreign networks, suggesting these groups exploit mixed signals (e.g., partial factuality) to avoid suspension.

values.value: Similar multilayer network frameworks have been adapted for cross-platform coordination detection, with each layer representing a different social media platform (e.g., Telegram, Facebook). These approaches leverage synchronized actions (e.g., co-hashtag, co-URL, co-mention) within short time frames (e.g., 5 minutes) to identify coordinated clusters, though performance may degrade due to platform-specific interaction patterns and data accessibility constraints.

2.2 Detection and characterization of co.text: Similar works explored cross-platform coordinated behavior through multilayer networks, where each layer represented a different social media platform [36, 37]. Other studies [11, 38] proposed multilayer networks with a temporal dimension, with each layer representing a time frame, allowing to analyze the evolution of coordinated communities. In summary, a growing number of studies are considering the wider complexities involved in coordinated behavior within their analyses. This suggests a trend towards a more comprehensive approach in understanding these dynamics.
2.2 Detection and characterization of co.relevance: Directly describes cross-platform validation via multilayer networks, including platform-specific layers (e.g., Telegram, Facebook) and temporal synchronization (5-minute windows). Highlights potential degradation due to platform heterogeneity and interaction patterns.

values.value: simulated evasion tactics to evaluate robustness against adaptive adversaries in coordinated behavior detection

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results.
Abstract.relevance: While not explicitly mentioning 'dynamic adversary testing,' the study's methodology inherently involves evaluating robustness against adaptive adversarial behaviors (e.g., foreign influence networks, conspiratorial groups) through nuanced, multifaceted detection and characterization techniques.

4.2 Characterization.text: We characterize each coordinated community according to five important facets of coordinated online behavior: (i) the degree of coordination, (ii) the degree to which members of the community make use of automation, (iii) account suspensions by the platform, (iv) the extent of political partisanship of the community, and (v) the degree to which the community shares non-factual news.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: The multifaceted characterization framework implicitly tests robustness against adaptive adversaries by analyzing diverse dimensions (e.g., automation, suspensions, partisanship) that adversaries could exploit or evade.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: Our nuanced results highlight the challenges of distinguishing genuine, organic activism from orchestrated influence campaigns.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: The study's composite analysis directly addresses the need to detect and differentiate between authentic and adversarial coordinated behaviors, aligning with the goal of dynamic adversary testing.

values.value: iterative network dismantling to analyze coordination at varying thresholds, enabling detection of adversarial communities at multiple levels of sophistication

4.1 Detection.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an **iterative network dismantling process**. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community **at all degrees of coordination**.
4.1 Detection.relevance: The iterative dismantling method inherently tests robustness by detecting coordinated communities at varying thresholds, simulating how adversaries might adapt their coordination intensity to evade detection.

5.1 Narratives.text: The analysis of the main coordinated communities revealed a striking predominance of communities aligned with Republican or far-right ideologies, and a single community associated with the Democrats. This distribution mirrors the political polarization observed during the election and highlights the better strategic use of social platforms by conservative groups.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: The detection of asymmetric coordination (e.g., far-right dominance) demonstrates the method's ability to uncover adversarial strategies that exploit platform vulnerabilities.

values.value: comparison of platform suspensions with coordination metrics to identify gaps in adversary mitigation (e.g., foreign influence networks evading detection)

5.2 Multifaceted characterization.text: Figure 8b shows that Twitter’s enforces suspensions towards users of CRE, but not towards BFR. In contrast, the QCO community, while showing lower automation, has a high rate of user suspensions, suggesting that factors beyond automation contribute to Twitter’s suspension decisions. These findings suggest complex, non-linear relationships between automation and suspensions: high automation doesn’t always result in suspensions, and vice versa.
5.2 Multifaceted characterization.relevance: This analysis explicitly tests the platform's robustness against adversaries by comparing suspension patterns with coordination/automation metrics, revealing evasion tactics (e.g., BFR's high coordination but low suspensions).

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a **diminished efficacy – or attention – from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups**. Paramount among them are the **foreign influence networks** that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Directly addresses dynamic adversary testing by evaluating the platform's failure to mitigate sophisticated adversaries (e.g., foreign influence networks), highlighting gaps in robustness.

Methods (Section 4.2).relevance: Implies a trade-off in accuracy for non-English users due to reliance on a universal (less language-specific) score.

Discussion (Section 6.4).text: Additionally, methods such as Botometer may not only suffer from these restrictions but also come with other intrinsic limitations.
Discussion (Section 6.4).relevance: Acknowledges limitations in Botometer, which may include reduced performance for non-primary languages.

Dataset.text: We collected a large dataset of tweets related to the 2020 US Presidential Election using the Twitter Streaming Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). The data collection period covered one month before and one month after Election Day, from October 2 to December 2, 2020. During this period, we collected all the tweets mentioning at least one hashtag from a set of predefined neutral and politically polarized hashtags related to the debate. Additionally, we collected all tweets mentioning official party accounts or other relevant official political accounts using predefined mentions as keywords. Our dataset includes a total of 263,518,037 tweets, posted by 15,288,527 distinct users.
Dataset.relevance: Directly describes the primary dataset used in the study, including platform origin (Twitter), collection methodology (Twitter Streaming API), and dataset size (263,518,037 tweets).

Dataset.text: The data collection period covered one month before and one month after Election Day, from October 2 to December 2, 2020.
Dataset.relevance: Directly specifies the exact start and end dates of the data collection period in ISO 8601-compatible format (YYYY-MM-DD).

4 Methods.text: All network-based coordination detection frameworks identify coordinated groups of users via community detection [9, 10, 12]. Although many community detection algorithms can be used for this task, the vast majority of existing works leverage the **Louvain algorithm** [42]. In particular, Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process [9].
4 Methods.relevance: Direct reference to the Louvain algorithm as the primary coordination detection method, with citation to the foundational work (Nizzoli et al., 2021) and its iterative application for detecting coordinated communities in the 2020 US election dataset.

4 Methods.text: Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the **multiscale backbone** [33] of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale.
4 Methods.relevance: Explicit mention of 'multiscale backbone' as a critical preprocessing step for coordination detection, integrated into the Louvain-based framework. Cited as a state-of-the-art method for filtering user similarity networks.

4 Methods.text: The first step of the method by Nizzoli et al. involves building a **Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) co-retweet network** filtered using a backbone strategy [33], on which we perform community detection at different coordination levels, so as to detect coordinated communities.
4 Methods.relevance: Describes the foundational network construction method (TF-IDF co-retweet network) as the input to the Louvain algorithm for coordination detection. This is a core component of the detection pipeline.

4 Methods.text: each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] Being based on pairwise similarities, user similarity networks are typically too big to be analyzed straight away. Therefore, all network-based coordination detection frameworks include a filtering step to prune irrelevant edges and disconnected nodes from the network. Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. [...] All network-based coordination detection frameworks identify coordinated groups of users via community detection. [...] Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process. [...] In [9], this coordination score is used to build a coordination curve for each community that quantifies the fraction of community members at any given coordination score.
4 Methods.relevance: Direct description of the technical pipeline for extracting behavioral coordination features, including vectorization, similarity computation, network filtering, community detection, and coordination quantification.

4.1 Detection.text: Similarities between users can be observed across many behavioral dimensions. Among them, retweeting behavior similarity is by far the most widely used. [...] The TF-IDF weighting scheme diminishes the influence of widely popular (i.e., viral) tweets and amplifies the contribution of retweets targeting less popular tweets. This approach is particularly effective at identifying suspicious behaviors and coordination that manifest through the retweeting of not-so-popular posts. [...] Edge weights in this network are proxies for the degree of coordination. [...] the multiscale backbone of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale. [...] coordination curve for each community that quantifies the fraction of community members at any given coordination score.
4.1 Detection.relevance: Explicitly describes the behavioral features (retweet timing, co-retweet networks, backbone thresholds) and their role in quantifying coordination via similarity distributions and curves.

4.2 Characterization.text: Here we resort to Botometer v4 to obtain an estimate of the degree of automation in Twitter accounts. [...] To assess the degree of automation within a community, we compute the mean automation score of its members. [...] We rely on Media Bias/Fact Check (MBFC) to obtain an extensive list of news outlets and the corresponding political bias scores. [...] We then compute the political partisanship score for each member of a coordinated community. [...] MBFC assigns factual ratings to each news outlet according to six ordinal values that range from very high, to very low factuality. [...] The suspensions score for a coordinated community is then computed as the fraction of the members of that community that have been suspended for policy violations. [...] the area under the coordination curve [as a] community coordination score ∈[0, 1].
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Directly enumerates the quantitative behavioral features used to characterize coordination, including automation, bias, factuality, suspensions, and coordination metrics.

4.2 Characterization.text: We obtain the suspension status of a Twitter account directly from Twitter’s APIs, which provide a distinct error code when an account is suspended [51–53]. [...] We rely on Media Bias/Fact Check (MBFC) to obtain an extensive list of news outlets and the corresponding political bias scores. MBFC is a well-known resource that provides expert-driven ratings of the political bias and factual accuracy of many news outlets.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Directly describes the two primary ground truth labeling methods used: (1) Platform-supplied suspension labels via Twitter API, and (2) Expert-driven ratings from MBFC for political bias/factuality. These serve as the study's ground truth for harmfulness and partisanship metrics.

4 Methods.text: we measure user similarities based on their retweeting activity. In detail, each user is defined by the TF-IDF weighted vector of the tweets they retweeted. Pairwise similarities between all users are computed as the cosine similarity of their user vectors. [...] The TF-IDF weighting scheme diminishes the influence of widely popular tweets and amplifies the contribution of retweets targeting less popular tweets. [...] Pairwise similarities are converted into a weighted undirected user similarity network, which encodes behavioral and interaction patterns between users. [...] Nizzoli et al. propose extracting the multiscale backbone [33] of the user similarity network as the filtering technique. This approach allows retaining all statistically significant network structures, independently of their scale.
4 Methods.relevance: Directly describes the graph construction methodology including TF-IDF weighting, cosine similarity for edge weights, and multiscale backbone filtering for network pruning. The method focuses on retweet-based coordination detection, which is the core interaction graph type in this study.

values.value: Louvain community detection on iterative network dismantling for multi-level coordination analysis

4 Methods.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an iterative network dismantling process [9]. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community at all degrees of coordination. As such, it provides more nuanced results with respect to the methods that apply fixed and arbitrary edge weight thresholds, which allow analyzing only a single snapshot of the user similarity network.
4 Methods.relevance: Describes the community detection methodology applied to the constructed graph, which is a critical component of the graph analysis pipeline for identifying coordinated groups at varying coordination thresholds.

4.2 Characterization.text: Here we resort to Botometer v4 [48] to obtain an estimate of the degree of automation in Twitter accounts.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Direct mention of Botometer v4 as the baseline method for bot detection, including version specification.

4.1 Detection.relevance: Explicit reference to Louvain algorithm as a baseline for community detection, a key step in coordination analysis.

4.1 Detection.relevance: TF-IDF is explicitly named as the baseline method for weighting user vectors in similarity computation.

values.value: Organic activism (e.g., Biafrans advocating for independence or Hong Kong protesters) may be misclassified as malicious coordination due to high coordination scores but low partisanship/nonfactuality, requiring nuanced differentiation between genuine grassroots movements and orchestrated influence campaigns.

6 Discussion.text: The intricate nature of online coordination, coupled with the diverse range of heterogeneous coordinated behaviors that we observed, presents inherent challenges in their detection and disambiguation. [...] our results underscore the necessity for nuanced methodological approaches to accurately study these phenomena and effectively distinguish between malicious forms of coordination and neutral or benign ones.
6 Discussion.relevance: Explicitly addresses the risk of false positives in detecting coordination, highlighting the challenge of distinguishing organic activism (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) from malicious coordination, which aligns with the property's focus on error modes in classification.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: communities of moderate parties tend to exhibit smaller plots featuring moderate or low levels in the majority of facets. This pattern suggests organic, harmless, and authentic forms of engagement, potentially indicative of genuine activism rather than deceptive or manipulative practices.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Provides a concrete example of how low-harm communities (e.g., moderate parties) might be falsely flagged if coordination alone is used as a criterion, reinforcing the need for multifaceted analysis to mitigate false positives.

5.1 Narratives.text: communities with high coordination but low partisanship and nonfactuality may reflect organic activism that ignites or reinforces public demonstrations and societal change, reminiscent of the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong and similar movements in Nigeria.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Directly illustrates the false positive scenario where highly coordinated but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) could be misclassified without contextual analysis of partisanship/nonfactuality.

values.value: Mitigation strategies include multifaceted characterization (e.g., combining coordination scores with automation, partisanship, factuality, and suspension metrics) to differentiate genuine activism (low partisanship/nonfactuality) from harmful coordination (high partisanship/nonfactuality).

4.2 Characterization.text: Overall, our new approach to the characterization of coordinated communities offers a comprehensive and nuanced depiction of online coordination. [...] we also compute a composite measure for these facets, which enables comparative analyses across varied behaviors and forms of coordination.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: Describes the methodological solution (multifaceted analysis) to reduce false positives by integrating multiple dimensions (e.g., automation, partisanship) beyond coordination alone.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: The analysis of the size and shape of these fingerprints contributes to the identification of genuine grassroots movements and to the understanding of harmful and inauthentic coordinated behavior, thus contributing to the ongoing efforts aimed at safeguarding the health and integrity of the online political discourse.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: Explicitly states that the composite analysis helps distinguish genuine activism from harmful coordination, directly addressing false positive mitigation.

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results. [...] We also reveal a large use of automation by far-right foreign influence and conspiratorial communities. Conversely, left-leaning supporters were overall less coordinated and engaged primarily in harmless, factual communication.
Abstract.relevance: Supports the distinction between harmful (high automation/partisanship) and harmless (low coordination/factual) groups, reinforcing the mitigation strategy of using multifaceted metrics.

values.value: Error modes include over-reliance on coordination scores alone, which may misclassify highly organized but non-malicious groups (e.g., Biafrans, Hong Kong protesters) as harmful, or under-detect foreign influence networks (e.g., Iranian Restart movement) due to mixed factuality/partisanship signals.

6 Discussion.text: The identification of foreign influence networks highlights the intricacy of online debates and the need for a nuanced strategy to comprehend and counteract potentially manipulative activities. [...] Similarly, the presence of conspiratorial communities highlights the potential for polarizing, divisive conversations that could damage social cohesion.
6 Discussion.relevance: Identifies two error modes: (1) missing foreign influence networks with mixed signals, and (2) conflating divisive but organic activism with malicious coordination.

5.1 Narratives.text: foreign influence networks show diverse balance between factual and non-factual content as a means of legitimizing their cause while promoting their strategic objectives. [...] The use of factuality may be instrumental in gathering support and credibility, especially when reaching out beyond their immediate community to influence broader discussions.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: Explains how foreign networks (e.g., Iranian Restart) may evade detection by blending factual/nonfactual content, creating false negatives.

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a diminished efficacy—or attention—from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups. Paramount among them are the foreign influence networks that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Highlights the platform's failure to detect foreign networks, suggesting these groups exploit mixed signals (e.g., partial factuality) to avoid suspension.

values.value: Similar multilayer network frameworks have been adapted for cross-platform coordination detection, with each layer representing a different social media platform (e.g., Telegram, Facebook). These approaches leverage synchronized actions (e.g., co-hashtag, co-URL, co-mention) within short time frames (e.g., 5 minutes) to identify coordinated clusters, though performance may degrade due to platform-specific interaction patterns and data accessibility constraints.

2.2 Detection and characterization of co.text: Similar works explored cross-platform coordinated behavior through multilayer networks, where each layer represented a different social media platform [36, 37]. Other studies [11, 38] proposed multilayer networks with a temporal dimension, with each layer representing a time frame, allowing to analyze the evolution of coordinated communities. In summary, a growing number of studies are considering the wider complexities involved in coordinated behavior within their analyses. This suggests a trend towards a more comprehensive approach in understanding these dynamics.
2.2 Detection and characterization of co.relevance: Directly describes cross-platform validation via multilayer networks, including platform-specific layers (e.g., Telegram, Facebook) and temporal synchronization (5-minute windows). Highlights potential degradation due to platform heterogeneity and interaction patterns.

values.value: simulated evasion tactics to evaluate robustness against adaptive adversaries in coordinated behavior detection

Abstract.text: Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results.
Abstract.relevance: While not explicitly mentioning 'dynamic adversary testing,' the study's methodology inherently involves evaluating robustness against adaptive adversarial behaviors (e.g., foreign influence networks, conspiratorial groups) through nuanced, multifaceted detection and characterization techniques.

4.2 Characterization.text: We characterize each coordinated community according to five important facets of coordinated online behavior: (i) the degree of coordination, (ii) the degree to which members of the community make use of automation, (iii) account suspensions by the platform, (iv) the extent of political partisanship of the community, and (v) the degree to which the community shares non-factual news.
4.2 Characterization.relevance: The multifaceted characterization framework implicitly tests robustness against adaptive adversaries by analyzing diverse dimensions (e.g., automation, suspensions, partisanship) that adversaries could exploit or evade.

5.3 Composite characterization.text: Our nuanced results highlight the challenges of distinguishing genuine, organic activism from orchestrated influence campaigns.
5.3 Composite characterization.relevance: The study's composite analysis directly addresses the need to detect and differentiate between authentic and adversarial coordinated behaviors, aligning with the goal of dynamic adversary testing.

values.value: iterative network dismantling to analyze coordination at varying thresholds, enabling detection of adversarial communities at multiple levels of sophistication

4.1 Detection.text: Nizzoli et al. proposed to perform Louvain community detection within an **iterative network dismantling process**. This approach allows to analyze the structure and behavior of each coordinated community **at all degrees of coordination**.
4.1 Detection.relevance: The iterative dismantling method inherently tests robustness by detecting coordinated communities at varying thresholds, simulating how adversaries might adapt their coordination intensity to evade detection.

5.1 Narratives.text: The analysis of the main coordinated communities revealed a striking predominance of communities aligned with Republican or far-right ideologies, and a single community associated with the Democrats. This distribution mirrors the political polarization observed during the election and highlights the better strategic use of social platforms by conservative groups.
5.1 Narratives.relevance: The detection of asymmetric coordination (e.g., far-right dominance) demonstrates the method's ability to uncover adversarial strategies that exploit platform vulnerabilities.

values.value: comparison of platform suspensions with coordination metrics to identify gaps in adversary mitigation (e.g., foreign influence networks evading detection)

5.2 Multifaceted characterization.text: Figure 8b shows that Twitter’s enforces suspensions towards users of CRE, but not towards BFR. In contrast, the QCO community, while showing lower automation, has a high rate of user suspensions, suggesting that factors beyond automation contribute to Twitter’s suspension decisions. These findings suggest complex, non-linear relationships between automation and suspensions: high automation doesn’t always result in suspensions, and vice versa.
5.2 Multifaceted characterization.relevance: This analysis explicitly tests the platform's robustness against adversaries by comparing suspension patterns with coordination/automation metrics, revealing evasion tactics (e.g., BFR's high coordination but low suspensions).

6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.text: our study possibly provides some insights in this regard, as part of our findings indicate a **diminished efficacy – or attention – from Twitter in detecting and moderating certain specific categories of coordinated groups**. Paramount among them are the **foreign influence networks** that tampered with the US 2020 online debate.
6.3 Securing the integrity of online pol.relevance: Directly addresses dynamic adversary testing by evaluating the platform's failure to mitigate sophisticated adversaries (e.g., foreign influence networks), highlighting gaps in robustness.

Methods (Section 4.2).text: For users who communicate in English, we use Botometer English language score, whereas for all other users we utilize the universal score.
Methods (Section 4.2).relevance: Directly specifies language support for Botometer automation detection, distinguishing English (primary) from universal (non-English).

Results (Section 5.1).text: Figure 4 shows the predominant language used by the members of each coordinated community. For the communities in this group, the analysis indicates a user base speaking both the native language and English.
Results (Section 5.1).relevance: Explicitly mentions multilingual communities (Chinese, Japanese, French, Arabic) alongside English, confirming support for non-primary languages.
